instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00244: What is 820-00244? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4: What is PM_SLP_S4? This is a typo of PM_SLP_S4_L When you see PM_SLP_S4, assume they meant to type PM_SLP_S4_L.
definitions.PP5V_G3H: What is PP5V_G3H? PP5V_G3H is a 5v rail present when the machine is in a G3H mechanical off state.
definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .

threads.title: Macbook 12 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)
threads.message:
Hi Macbook when connected charger wont start
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> 8.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_G3H</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> 5v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v
Missing S4 rails and on Bios SPI rails I have 1.5v i think should be 3.3v ,try to remove bios still showing 1.5v ,No <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4</SIGNAL> also

threads.title: Macbook 12 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)
threads.message:
Is probably better to return it, as all <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> bulshit.

"Bios SPI rails I have 1.5v i think should be 3.3v"
Do you mean data lines?
Because power comes from <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL>.
When PCH takes access to SPI chip, MOSI/MISO lines will drop to 0V.
Another reason to doubt about f***g micro in your case.

threads.message: Yes data lines ,I have <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> 3.3v but all data lines is 1.5v ,could be <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> cause this

threads.title: Macbook 12 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)
threads.message: CPU doesn't have to get hot to be dead. CPU fails on this model at alarming rates anyways, so it's prob a lost cause

threads.title: Macbook 12 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)
threads.message: Any test that I can confirm is CPU dead 100% ?

threads.title: Macbook 12 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)
threads.message: Update I found that my <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_LIO</SIGNAL> is 15v and <SIGNAL>PP1V2_S5SW</SIGNAL> 0V ,on <CHIP>U8130</CHIP> found that <SIGNAL>P1V2S5SW_HSMUX_EN_R</SIGNAL> is only 0.5v and its coming from <CHIP>U3100</CHIP> ,any clue ??

threads.title: Macbook 12 (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00244</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>)
threads.message:
I fix maybe 15% of them. Unless they come in for water damage they are almost always toast! Worst product apple has ever made.
what is your resistance to ground on the CPU power rails?
You can solder off the inductors on the board and see if the short is on the CPU side. But it is...
These machines are awful.

I have ordered a stencil for these processors and copper shims to replace the crap iphone X heat conducting paste. I have the nozzle on the way for my BGA rework machine. I figured I would change a few of these processors and see if I can fix any. I have a drawer full of these boards all with CPU drama.. The processors are not that expensive but the working boards sure are!
